CatDescriptText: Vern Stern, airlines employee, East Liberty and George Luster, bartender, Fifth Ward, were part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, October 28, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you think Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., should come to Pittsburgh and take over the pastorate of a church, or should he remain in the South and continue his crusade?  Mr. Stern's answer reads: "It would be an advantage to Pittsburgh if he did, because Pittsburgh is one of the biggest Southern-Northern towns in the country.  It always has been - and it needs a lot of cleaning up.  There's a tremendous educational job needed, because only some of the people have begun to fight for equal rights."  Mr. Luster's answer reads: "He could crusade up here as well as in the South, because there's the same type of crusading needed here..."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Vern Stern wearing zippered jacket with breast pockets, eyeglasses, and hats, standing in front of automobiles and buildings; Portrait of George Luster wearing flecked zippered jacket and hat, standing in front of buildings
